Award.AwardTitle: I/UCRC FRP: Collaborative Research on Event-based Analytics for Enhanced Prognostics Design in a Big Data Environment

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed work seeks to investigate event-based modeling to deal with high-dimensional and heterogeneous data environments in order to enhance prognostics design with adaptive control of data collection and rapid maintenance decision-making to apply data analytics to the software development process. The event-based approach is explored given its potential to reduce temporal redundancy while preserving the machine dynamics. Event-based approaches have not been fully explored for prognostics applications with continuous signal inputs, such as sensor measurements. The proposed approach represents a paradigm shift in data modeling prognostic system design and holds the potential to help address the fundamental issues of big data in the areas of volume, velocity and variety. Results will be validated using various data collected from a fleet of electric vehicles.

The outcomes of the proposed work have the potential for significant impact in the manufacturing sector in the area of prognostics and health monitoring. The resulting approach has the potential to create more efficient systems that can more rapidly adapt and respond to critical issues. The work is supported by the Industry Advisory Board as well as individual industry members of the center and has the potential to extend the centers portfolio through expansion into the area of event-driven modeling, big data reduction and mining for improved industrial efficiency. The center will involve graduate students and undergraduates in the work.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objectives of this project are to further the science of prognostics by developing an advanced event based prognostic and health management method, which can provide insightful information and value from the ever increasing volume of data that exists, and is being generated, for industrial equipment and processes. This is a fundamental analysis paradigm shift from the traditional continuous sensor features- and supervised learning-based health monitoring and prognostic algorithms for equipment, to methods that can compact representations of sensory signals to discrete events.  From a data volume perspective, dealing with the discrete events can effectively reduce the data storage required, and also provide a trigger for the data acquisition to capture higher frequency data when an event of interest occurs.  In addition, the event-based processing method is more suited for online learning health models that improve and grow over time; thus more insightful and accurate machine health information can be captured using this event based approach.  For industrial systems, providing more value and insight for their fleet of assets and processes should allow them to take corrective action or conduct critical maintenance prior to machine failure, process degradation, or poor part quality occurs. Thus, this event based big data analysis methodology can provide significant savings. Improvements in quality, productivity, and the reduction in downtime can be achieved by providing real-time actionable information derived from all the available data sources. 

Through this project, a methodology and set of tools for processing big industrial data sets using event-based concepts and analysis methods have been developed. The event-based analysis methods are perfectly suited for industrial big data analytic problems since they not only provide a compact and intuitive representation of the data, they also use the event analysis for a reconfigurable sampling rate and acquisition of the various data signals and sources.

This reduces the data storage required and more importantly, extracts the value and meaning from these large data sets which can be used to predict and prevent machine failures, reduce process disruptions, and improve product quality (manufacturing applications). The obtained results show promise, and the potential impacts on reducing the data volume and improving the value in manufacturing and industrial big data monitoring applications are quite significant. The same set of methodologies and algorithms could be used for a broader set of applications, including big data in health care, transportation, and infrastructure (power grid) applications.

The IMS Center has made great strides in broadening the application of proposed event-based approach to a broader range of applications that deal with certain types of data, such as maintenance and product quality.

The platform and app developed through this effort with an IMS Center member was presented at the 2016 IMTS show—an event that garnered media coverage from a number of outlets. This IMS Center member will continue to work with the Center on refining and further developing this solution, with a goal of offering the developed application as a service to its customers. This commercialization will not only enhance the reputation of the Center, it will also ensure that the technologies developed under this project are more broadly disseminated. 

Through working on this effort, five graduate students have been involved in the ball crew health monitoring project and have gained valuable experience in terms of designing data acquisition systems, streamlining data, developing minimal-sensing PHM techniques, cloud-based analytics and mobile APP development. Such unique set of skills would not have been gained by IMS graduate students without conducting this hands-on research with industry.

The IMS Center is using industry testbeds to challenge our researchers to pursue applied engineering and scientific work in real factory and industrial settings. The fundamental goals are to cultivate engineers with a better understanding about human, organizational, and real-world issues involved in scientific and engineering work. The IMS researchers are also involved in exploring industry standardization of technologies, which is encouraging faster adaptation of newly developed methods. The PI has given several keynote speeches on manufacturing big data, which are done to influence leaders in industry, government, and academia and push the frontier of the technology. Finally, the inclusion of an undergraduate student on this project--and the continued inclusion of undergraduates students in the Center's research efforts--may result in increased interest in this area of research, as well as in the STEM fields in general.
